adjective.description: Reaching a high or the highest degree; very great.
Furthest from the center or a given point; outermost.

noun.description: Either of two abstract things that are as different from each other as possible.
examples: unbridled talk at one extreme and total silence at the other

noun.description: The subject or predicate in a proposition, or the major or minor term in a syllogism (as contrasted with the middle term).

phrases: In the recesses of the Middle East where extremes meet, dismay at the loss of innocent lives was tempered with happier emotions ranging from quiet satisfaction to open celebration.
This is a place of ambivalence, a place where extremes meet.
Genovese is, it should be said, an illuminating example of the way in which left-wing and right-wing extremes meet in a love of tyranny and a hatred of freedom.
Ironically enough, in Gramsci the extremes meet, confirming the overlapping lineage of both left and right ideologies.
John and Yoko were people whose fantastic freedom became - where extremes meet - a fantastic prison.
origin: Late Middle English: via Old French from Latin extremus outermost, utmost, superlative of exterus outer.
